newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Takeover rumours spur Czech IPB shares.
newsitem.headline: Takeover rumours spur Czech IPB shares.

text.p: Shares of Czech IPB rose the maximum allowed five percent on the Prague bourse on Tuesday, spurred by reports that Nomura and ING are leading candidates to take a government-held stake in the bank.
IPB shares rose 15 crowns to 331 at the bourse's daily price fixing, their second consecutive five percent jump after several months of holding steady at the 300 crown level.

"If you were to bring in a foreign partner of the caliabre of the two banks mentioned, that addresses questions that have been hovering around IPB on its perceived lack of corporate structure and transparency," said Jay King of Wood and Company.

The bank has been widely criticised for being the least transparent in its dealings of the four major Czech banks, especially during a recent spending spree that has seen it quietly buy large stakes in several firms.

The rumours began last weekend after Finance Minister Ivan Kocarnik said IPB was first in line among the big Czech banks for further privatisation, adding that a strong foreign strategic partner would be the most likely beneficiary of any selloff.
He did not give any timetable for the selloff. The government currently holds about a 30 percent stake in the bank, the country's fourth largest.
